With the entire world of knowledge just a few mouse-clicks away, it has never been easier than it is right now to learn something new and unexpected every day. Here are a few simple ways to make expanding your horizons a part of your daily routine: Subscribe to Wikipedia’s “Featured Article” list. Every day, Wikipedia posts an article selected from its vast repository of entries to it’s Daily-article-l subscribers. If you were a subscriber today, you would have recently discovered that Daylight Saving Time was first proposed by William Willett in 1907 and adopted during World War I as a way to conserve coal. You might have also been interested to find out that Kazakhstan discontinued Daylight Saving Time in 2005 because of alleged health risks associated with changed sleep patterns.Read The Free Dictionary’s homepage or subscribe to its feeds. The Free Dictionary has several daily features on its front page, including Article of the Day (RSS), In the News (RSS), This Day in History (RSS), and Today’s Birthday (RSS). One recent day’s stories told the history of the Hell’s Angels, the identity of the new “7 Wonders of the World”, the origin of the first cultured pearl, and the life story of one of the world’s most prominent tenors.Subscribe to the feed at Your Daily Art (RSS). Every day you’ll be confronted with a classic work of art to contemplate, along with a few notes about the piece. If you were subscribed right now, you might have recently seen Man Ray’s intriguing and playful “Le Violin d’Ingres” and Frank Weston Benson’s luminous “Red and Gold”.Subscribe to the feeds at Did You Know? and Tell Me Why?. These sites are both run by an R. Edmondson, who certainly knows a lot of stuff about a lot of stuff. Updates are slightly less than daily, but I like the two sites so much I couldn’t leave them off this list. If you were a subscriber to these sites, you’d have recently learned why clouds are white, what the European Union is, the French terms for the days of the week and the months of the year, and the history of the development of public health efforts in response to the hazards of the Industrial Revolution.Listen to podcasts like In Our Time and Radio Open Source. Radio Open Source is a daily interview/panel show covering everything from politics to science to art and literature to the greatness of the movie Groundhog Day. (At the moment, Radio Open Source is on summer hiatus, but subscribe anyway — they’ll be back!) For a history of the events and ideas that shaped the present, In Our Time is ideal: a weekly gathering of scholars discussing subjects as diverse as the life of Joan of Arc, theories of gravity, and what we know about the Permian-Triassic boundary. Subscribe to a handful of good, literary podcasts and get smart while you drive!

Learning every day is an idea that sounds good, but is difficult to pull off, and I say this from experience. However, I found ways for myself to move towards this ideal, and so far they seem to be working for me. There are many ways to learn something new, but doing so everyday is where we get stuck, as we never actively take out time to do so. Another place where we fail is retaining whatever we have learnt today. I live my life guided by my daily checklists, and learning every day is a task that appears there. But keeping it vague in the checklist means it's never going to get crossed off. So I give myself a lot of options to accomplish it. A sample check list looks like this: ReadExerciseLearn viaNewspaperMagazine articleResearch article / White papersMOOCTed talkYouTube tutorialsNetworkingSo on and so forthThe idea is that if I learn something from any of the options mentioned in the checklist, I have achieved something. But this is partial learning, because it's not complete till you retain it for long. For retention, one can keep a learning journal. The learning journal need not have the entire description of what you've learnt, but can have the essentials. For example, Date - 10 Feb 2017Topic - cooking butter chickenSource - Sanjeev Kapoor's YouTube channelSummary - have noted down the recipe, or offlined the video.How I felt - the dish looked amazing, and have to try it out in the next party. (I feel this section should be there because it will tell you what kind of things you actually enjoyed learning about - an important step in self discovery)Of course, the contents of the journal, which will eventually become an amazing repository of all things you know, and options in the checklist can vary from person to person, but having it as a to-do item will help one actually actively learn something new everyday.

1. Understand Yourself If you don't understand yourself, start today. Find a mirror, and start a conversation with yourself. That's all you need to meet yourself. You'll see exactly what a stranger might see in you, and from that point, you can start to recognize your own behaviors and exercise some control over them. With a little bit of care -- like clipping the hedges -- you will take a new, more defined shape as an individual. 2. Become a Cultivator. Nothing happens overnight. All skills start with a seed, and you cultivate that seed over time. This is that seed: Become a cultivator. Remember that your job is to take care of your skills over time.It is impossible to LEARN all the skills you will need in a single week, month or even ye​ar. Learning new skills is the process of a lifetime. The cultivator understands that. 3. Learn to Pace Yourself Properly There is a reason you don't try to sprint through a marathon. You'll get tired, exhaust yourself early and the people that paced themselves will pass you. Few understand that this translates to work and self-work, but once you recognize that controlling your pace will affect your long-term, you'll soon understand that this is a skill worth learning a hundred times over. 4. Simplify With all things, seek simplification. In order to simplify, you must recognize and eliminate the unnecessary parts and leave only what is necessary. Does this explanation seem simple to you? 5. Become Visionary Instead of desiring or thinking about things, envision them. Figure out what it would take to get from point A to point B with visual, intense recognition of what it is that you want to create. You cannot be a visionary if you can't see what you want in your mind.The difference between someone that imagines and someone that envisions is simple: One is attempting to marry their vision with reality, while the other is trying to imagine something that they think is separate from reality. There are some tips to learn something new everyday I hope this is very useful to you.

Stanford scientists have demonstrated a technique for observing hundreds of neurons firing in the brain of a live mouse, in real time, and have linked that activity to long-term information storage. The unprecedented work could provide a useful tool for studying new therapies for neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer's. The researchers first used a gene therapy approach to cause the mouse's neurons to express a green fluorescent protein that was engineered to be sensitive to the presence of calcium ions. When a neuron fires, the cell naturally floods with calcium ions. Calcium stimulates the protein, causing the entire cell to fluoresce bright green. A tiny microscope implanted just above the mouse's hippocampus – a part of the brain that is critical for spatial and episodic memory – captures the light of roughly 700 neurons. The microscope is connected to a camera chip, which sends a digital version of the image to a computer screen. The computer then displays near real-time video of the mouse's brain activity as a mouse runs around a small enclosure, which the researchers call an arena. The neuronal firings look like tiny green fireworks, randomly bursting against a black background, but the scientists have deciphered clear patterns in the chaos. "We can literally figure out where the mouse is in the arena by looking at these lights," said Mark Schnizer, an associate professor of biology and of applied physics. When a mouse is scratching at the wall in a certain area of the arena, a specific neuron will fire and flash green. When the mouse scampers to a different area, the light from the first neuron fades and a new cell sparks up. "The hippocampus is very sensitive to where the animal is in its environment, and different cells respond to different parts of the arena," Schnitzer said. "Imagine walking around your office. Some of the neurons in your hippocampus light up when you're near your desk, and others fire when you're near your chair. This is how your brain makes a representative map of a space." The group has found that a mouse's neurons fire in the same patterns even when a month has passed between experiments. "The ability to come back and observe the same cells is very important for studying progressive brain diseases," Schnitzer said. For example, if a particular neuron in a test mouse stops functioning, as a result of normal neuronal death or a neurodegenerative disease, researchers could apply an experimental therapeutic agent and then expose the mouse to the same stimuli to see if the neuron's function returns. Although the technology can't be used on humans, mouse models are a common starting point for new therapies for human neurodegenerative diseases, and Schnitzer believes the system could be a very useful tool in evaluating pre-clinical research. (Image source- Mobile) Yesterday night at around 2 AM my cooler got stopped automatically. I tried to on/off it but it didn’t start. Today in the afternoon I opened it to check what the problem is. When I look closely the power wire connecting to the motor was burnt from inside. So, I took another piece of wire and replaced it with the damaged one. I did connections and tried to check it is working or not before taping. When I switched ON the power supply, cooler didn’t start. It grew my tension because I thought the problem is in Motor itself and the main fear was where I will find an electrician in the lockdown. So, I thought to give it another try. I controlled my tension thoughts and tried to focus more on the problem. I checked the winding and connection again closely. As I focused more I found that the connection was loose. I mean I just connected wires loosely (but not much loosely). This time I did the connection again and bind wires tightly. I applied tape also before checking. And then I switched ON. The cooler start working properly. What I learned today and how you can learn something daily? A little loose connection, be it in a relationship, parenting, marketing, planning or in a career can destroy everything. A less focused mind never gives satisfying results. So, whatever stuff you do there is always a life lesson to learn. You just have to clear your thoughts and learn from the silly mistakes. Make this a habit that whenever you will find a problem next time, you will not leave anything loose. Be Happy My Friend. Bheem Lambora

Reading is a great way to learn new things. Think of topics that you are interested in and dive into some books. Go to you local library to check them out for free. Amazon is a great source of finding books and the reviews are nice to read to see if the book is right for you want to learn. Taking classes is another way. Not necessarily formal classes at a university but there are tons of places to find free or low cost courses on just about anything. Online Courses - Learn Anything, On Your Schedule | Udemy and Coursera | Online Courses From Top Universities. Join for Free are fantastic sites to find courses, often taught by the top universities of the world. I am also a huge fan of documentaries. If you have cable television, there are tons of documentaries everyday. There are also great videos on YouTube that are posted by different universities, publishing companies, and journalists about a vast array of topics. Lastly, and I feel most importantly, keep an open mind in anything you do. You don’t always have to agree with someone to be able to see where they are coming from. Talk with people you wouldn’t normally talk with about topics you are set in your mind about. Don’t try to prove anyone that your view is right and see why that person views something the way they do. In almost any issue, there are many ways to view it. That doesn’t me you have to adopt it, but learning other view points on the same issue can really enlighten you. Hope this helps!

The key to starting and keeping new habits is to Start with a small daily goal. This is something I did personally several years back and have really made it part of my daily routine. My goal was to read one book per month. I now read through books at a pace of 2–3 per month. Having a goal to finish a book a week or a book a month sounds very daunting. However, if I tell you to read 10 pages per day, would that sound reasonable? Most self-help/non-fiction books in this genre are in the 250 page range. That means with a simple 10 page/day plan, you finish one book per month. Once you have this mindset, tie the daily goal to something you already do. Start to read while you drink your coffee or for 10–15 minutes before you go to bed. Once this 10 page/day habit gets ties to something you are already doing, then you will find that you’ll plow straight through these books. It is because of this simple 10 page/day mindset that I don’t believe people when they tell me they don’t have time to read. It really isn’t that hard to find some time and make some real progress. I actually wrote an article about this on my Quora Blog - Reading just 10 min/day can boost your engineering career. No time? I don’t believe you Reading is a great way to improve your skills and learn new things. If you are looking for some good book recommendations, I have several listed on my website and add new books every week or two, My Book Recommendations Now take this same mindset and apply it to any habit. Once you see it as just a small daily change, it will be much easier to stay on track and keep it up. A quick one: 1) Be curious and inquisitive about the world around us; 2) Be open to new ways of thinking and new ways of doing; 3) Be open-minded to all ideas, including crazy and weird ones, i.e. always be ready to play, explore and experiment with new things; 4) Embrace a beginner's mindset, and approach the world without any preconceived notions; 5) Act like a child, especially with the acute sense of wonder and discovery, but don't be childish; 6) Read, read, and read widely and deeply, both mainstream as well as fringe stuff, in order to garner expanded mental perspectives; 7) Don't be afraid to ask a lot of questions, including dumb ones; 8) Have a warm, sincere and genuine desire to meet and interact with people, all around us, as people are our greatest resource, as well as wonderful opportunity to learn, grow and change; 9) Don't be afraid to make mistakes and to face confusion, as they offer tremendous learning opportunities; 10) Always be ready to move out of our comfort zone, so as to stretch our intellectual muscles and physical prowess; 11) Accept that the digital world of today is always volatile, uncertain, complex and ambiguous, and so breaking old patterns and learning new things is our only way to keep up with the dynamic changes out there;  12) Invariably make sure that our rate of learning is equal if not greater that the rate of change in the digital world where we live, work and play;

Online resources are great for learning very diverse and interesting practical skills. The flipped aspect allows anyone to learn anywhere, anytime and at their pace. So where can we go to learn not only academic lessons but practical skills that help us lead enhanced lives? However, the internet has changed all of that, and nowadays, it is easy to find tutorials and helpful videos related to almost any niche or topic. The online resources listed below offer lots of education for just that. Explore each one carefully and dig for those bits of gold. They’re there, and the best part is they’re free. The content and tutorials are provided by some of the leading universities and institutions in the world, such as Stanford University, Yale University, Dartmouth College and MIT. The list of subjects covered is huge and includes History, Languages, Philosophy, Religion, Science, Maths, Engineering, Computers, Accounting, and so on. Units include challenging games and puzzles that stretch the imagination and exercise critical thinking capacity. It’s a fun and easy-to-navigate site that features rich and interesting content for kids ages 5–12. This is another highly interactive site with great visual learning quality. Observation plays a major role in learning, and learning doesn’t necessarily have to be bookish. You just got to know that your friend is allergic to corn, you did learn something [about him], right? So don’t limit yourself to learning only about subjects or facts from history. You never know when can you learn a different way to tie a tie just by observing someone or anything else for that matter. Let me tell you a small bit of story from Chanakya's life. He was the person who changed history by crowning Chandragupta Maurya as the king of a kingdom called Maghad( present-day Bihar). Whenever they tried to attack the existing king, they lost. Chanakya was disappointed to know that his tactics weren’t working. He went out to stroll when he saw a little boy with a plate full of rice. That boy took a bite and started crying. When his mother came to check on him, she said “HOW MANY TIMES HAVE I TOLD YOU NOT TO EAT FROM THE MIDDLE. ITS THE HOTTEST IN THE MIDDLE. START FROM THE SIDES.” You must be wondering, what did Chanakya do with this information or what's so special about it?? But this taught him the biggest lesson of the war. They always attacked the central Maghad, where the forces were the strongest. Thats when he realized where he was going wrong and changes his ways. The started attacking the villages of the boundaries of Maghad and slowly conquered the kingdom and THAT IS WHEN THE MIGHTY MAURYAN KINGDOM WAS ESTABLISHED. So observation matters! :)
